content: Known for her iconic diary, which young Jewish girl went into hiding with her family during World War II but was eventually discovered and died in a concentration camp?

The young Jewish girl you're referring to is Anne Frank. She gained international fame posthumously following the publication of her diary, which she wrote while hiding with her family in Amsterdam during World War II.

Anne Frank was born on June 12, 1929, in Frankfurt, Germany, to Otto and Edith Frank. Due to the increasing persecution of Jews by the Nazi regime, the family moved to Amsterdam in 1933. However, after the German invasion of the Netherlands in 1940, life became increasingly difficult for the Franks, and they went into hiding in July 1942 to evade deportation to concentration camps.

The Frank family, along with four others, hid in a secret annex above Otto Frank's former business premises on Prinsengracht Street. During this time, Anne documented her experiences, thoughts, and feelings in her diary, which she had received as a birthday gift just before going into hiding.

Unfortunately, on August 4, 1944, the hiding place was discovered, and all eight people were arrested and deported to concentration camps. Anne and her sister Margot were eventually transferred to the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp, where they both contracted typhus and died in February or March 1945, just weeks before the camp was liberated.

After the war, Anne's diary was found in the annex by one of the helpers, Miep Gies, who kept it safe until after the war. Otto Frank, the only survivor of the group, returned to Amsterdam and was given Anne's diary. It was later published in multiple languages and has become one of the most widely read accounts of the Holocaust, providing a poignant and personal perspective on the suffering endured by Jews during World War II.

Anne Frank's legacy lives on through her writings, which continue to educate and inspire people around the world about the importance of tolerance, compassion, and standing up against discrimination and hatred.
